data.title: Is It Time To Revisit USA Rare Earth (USAR) After Its Recent Share Price Swings
data.description:

  • The stock last closed at US$18.90, with returns of 9.7% over the past week, a 14.4% decline over the last 30 days, and gains of 33.6% year to date and 69.8% over the past year. That performance will catch the eye of anyone tracking shifts in risk and reward.

Approach 1: USA Rare Earth Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow model takes projected future cash flows, then discounts them back to today to estimate what the business might be worth now. It is essentially asking what those future dollars are worth in today‚Äôs terms.

For USA Rare Earth, the latest twelve month free cash flow (FCF) is a loss of $39.02 million. Analyst and model projections see FCF running through a mix of negative and positive years, with a projected $735.00 million in FCF for 2030. Beyond the explicit analyst horizon, Simply Wall St extends the cash flow path using a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity model.

Combining all of those discounted cash flows produces an estimated intrinsic value of about $203.77 per share. When this is compared with the recent share price of $18.90, the model suggests the stock trades at a 90.7% discount to this estimate, which indicates substantial potential upside based solely on these cash flow assumptions.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests USA Rare Earth is undervalued by 90.7%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 46 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for USA Rare Earth.

Approach 2: USA Rare Earth Price vs Book

For companies where book value is a meaningful anchor, the P/B ratio is a useful way to see how much investors are paying for each dollar of net assets. It is especially common in capital intensive sectors where tangible assets matter.

In general, higher growth expectations and lower perceived risk tend to support a higher P/B, while slower growth or higher risk usually justify a lower multiple. That is why it helps to look at a company‚Äôs P/B next to its sector and peers, rather than in isolation.

USA Rare Earth currently trades on a P/B ratio of 68.02x. This sits well above the Metals and Mining industry average P/B of 2.66x and above the peer group average of 8.63x. Simply Wall St also uses a ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù, which is a proprietary estimate of what the P/B should be after considering factors such as earnings growth, profit margins, the company‚Äôs risks, its industry and its market cap. This Fair Ratio can give you a more tailored anchor than a simple peer or industry comparison, because it adjusts for those company specific features.

On this framework, USA Rare Earth‚Äôs current P/B of 68.02x is higher than the Fair Ratio assessment would typically support.

Result: OVERVALUED

data.title: Is Grab Holdings (GRAB) Pricing Looked At Differently After Recent Share Price Weakness
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Grab Holdings is attractively priced at its current level, this article will walk through what the latest data suggests about its valuation.
  • The stock most recently closed at US$4.22, with returns of 3.7% decline over 7 days, 6.8% decline over 30 days, 16.9% decline year to date, 13.0% decline over 1 year, 28.7% over 3 years and 63.4% decline over 5 years, which may prompt questions about how the market is reassessing its potential and risks.
  • Recent coverage around Grab has continued to focus on its position as a super app in Southeast Asia, tying together ride hailing, deliveries and financial services and keeping investor attention on how its business model scales. This backdrop helps frame whether the current share price aligns with the fundamentals and the longer term story investors have in mind.
  • On Simply Wall St's valuation checks, Grab Holdings scores 3 out of 6, which suggests some measures flag potential undervaluation while others are more cautious. We will look at what different valuation approaches say about that mix, then finish with a way to tie all of these signals together more effectively.

Find out why Grab Holdings's -13.0% return over the last year is lagging behind its peers.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Grab Holdings Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model takes estimates of the cash a company could generate in the future and discounts those cash flows back to today, aiming to arrive at an intrinsic value per share.

For Grab Holdings, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve month free cash flow is a loss of about $50.6 million. Analysts provide explicit free cash flow estimates out to 2028, with Simply Wall St extrapolating further to build a 10 year view. Within that, projected free cash flow for 2028 is $1.29 billion, and the discounted values of projected cash flows from 2026 through 2035 range from roughly $728 million to $1.51 billion per year.

After discounting these projected cash flows back to today, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about $11.34 per share, compared with the recent share price of $4.22. That gap implies the stock is around 62.8% undervalued on this DCF view.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Grab Holdings is undervalued by 62.8%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 46 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Grab Holdings.

Approach 2: Grab Holdings Price vs Earnings

For a company that is generating earnings, the P/E ratio is a useful way to see what multiple of those earnings investors are currently willing to pay for each share. You can think of it as a quick check on how the market is weighing the trade off between what the business earns today, the growth investors hope for, and the risks they see.

A higher P/E can sometimes reflect stronger growth expectations or lower perceived risk, while a lower P/E can point to the opposite, or simply lower market enthusiasm. For Grab Holdings, the current P/E is 64.57x, compared with the Transportation industry average of 37.54x and a peer group average of 28.08x, so the shares are trading at a higher multiple than both these benchmarks.

Simply Wall St also uses a proprietary ‚ÄúFair Ratio‚Äù to estimate what a more suitable P/E could be, given factors like earnings growth, industry, profit margins, market cap and specific risks. Because it blends these elements, the Fair Ratio can be a more tailored reference point than a simple comparison with peers or the broader industry. Grab Holdings has a Fair Ratio of 25.27x, which is well below its current P/E of 64.57x, indicating that the shares are pricing in more optimism than this model supports.

Result: OVERVALUED

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Grab Holdings Narrative

For example, one investor might see Grab as worth US$8.20 per share based on higher margins and a future P/E of 37.0x, while another might anchor on US$6.65 with different growth and risk assumptions. data.title: Port Of Tauranga (NZSE:POT) One Off Gain Lifts EPS And Tests Bullish Narratives
data.description:
Port of Tauranga (NZSE:POT) has put up a clean set of H1 2026 numbers, with total revenue of NZ$239.7 million and basic EPS of NZ$0.168, alongside trailing 12 month revenue of NZ$483.8 million and EPS of NZ$0.272. The company has seen revenue move from NZ$217.4 million and EPS of NZ$0.065 in H1 2024 to NZ$225.0 million and EPS of NZ$0.089 in H1 2025, before reaching NZ$239.7 million and EPS of NZ$0.168 in the latest half. A trailing net profit margin of 37.9% highlights how much of that topline is currently flowing through to the bottom line.

  • What stands out against a more bullish view is that the 76.7% earnings rise over the last year is not all from day to day port activity. The NZ$46.7 million single gain sits next to underlying net income of NZ$173.4 million in H2 2025 and NZ$103.8 million in H1 2025, so anyone leaning bullish needs to separate that one off item from the recurring profit story.
    • Supporters who focus on the 76.7% earnings growth and 37.9% margin can point to the NZ$183.4 million trailing profit, but the one off gain means the underlying run rate is lower than the headline suggests.

data.title: Autodesk (ADSK) Margin Compression Challenges Bullish Earnings Growth Narrative After FY 2026 Results
data.description:
Autodesk (ADSK) has wrapped up FY 2026 with Q4 revenue of US$1.96b and basic EPS of US$1.49, alongside trailing twelve month revenue of US$7.21b and EPS of US$5.28, setting a clear reference point for how the business is currently performing. Over recent periods, the company has seen revenue move from US$6.13b on a trailing basis in FY 2025 to US$7.21b in FY 2026, while trailing EPS shifted from US$5.17 to US$5.28. This gives investors a clearer view of how top line scale and per share earnings are tracking together ahead of any debate about where margins might head next.

See our full analysis for Autodesk.

With the headline numbers in place, the next step is to set these results against the most widely held stories about Autodesk, highlighting where the recent earnings support those narratives and where the margin and growth profile may tell a different story.

See what the community is saying about Autodesk

Advertisement

Margins Slip As Profit Growth Trails Revenue

  • On a trailing basis, net income sits at US$1.1b on US$7.2b of revenue, which equates to a 15.6% net margin compared with 18.1% a year earlier, while earnings grew 1.1% over the past year versus a 1.8% per year average over five years.
  • Bears focus on this margin pressure, arguing that heavier cloud, AI and transaction model costs could keep profitability under strain, and the current data lines up with several of those concerns:
    • Management has highlighted that the new transaction model and annual billings can temporarily flatter billings and free cash flow, which bears see as a risk if those boosts fade while the trailing net margin is already at 15.6%.
    • They also point out that cloud and AI workloads are expected to weigh on gross margin and that management itself flags potential operating margin headwinds in fiscal 2027, which is consistent with the recent move from 18.1% to 15.6% net margin.
Skeptics argue these FY 2026 margins hint at a tougher profit path ahead than the share price implies, and they are watching closely to see if cost and pricing plans can offset cloud and transaction model headwinds. üêª Autodesk Bear Case

Revenue And EPS Step Up, But Growth Pace Looks Measured

  • Quarterly revenue progressed from US$1,570m in Q3 FY 2025 to US$1,957m in Q4 FY 2026, and basic EPS moved from US$1.28 to US$1.49 over the same Q3 FY 2025 to Q4 FY 2026 comparison, while trailing twelve month EPS edged from US$5.17 to US$5.28.
  • Consensus narrative talks about expanding cloud and AI driven workflows supporting strong long term demand, yet the recent numbers paint a more measured earnings pace, which creates a gap investors need to watch:
    • Analysts expect earnings to grow about 20.3% per year over the next three years, but the latest one year earnings growth rate of 1.1% is well below that figure, so the current run rate has not yet caught up with those expectations.
    • At the same time, trailing revenue is US$7.2b and is forecast to grow 9.6% per year, which is a solid absolute level but slightly below the 10.3% revenue growth forecast for the broader US market, so Autodesk will need its product mix and pricing to work hard to deliver the higher earnings growth that is being modeled.

Mixed Valuation Signals Around A US$245.89 Share Price

  • With the stock at US$245.89, it trades on a 46.3x P/E, below a 50x peer average but above the 26.4x US software industry, while a DCF fair value of about US$312.43 and an analyst price target of roughly US$337.33 both sit above the current price.
  • Bulls argue that Autodesk‚Äôs position in cloud based AEC and manufacturing workflows, plus AI features, justify that premium P/E and the upside implied by models and targets, and today‚Äôs numbers give them some support but also a few checks:
    • Support comes from the combination of high recurring software revenue, US$7.2b in trailing sales and forecasts for roughly 12% annual revenue growth with earnings expected to reach about US$2.0b by around 2028, which helps explain why models point to DCF fair value above the current share price.
    • The tension is that current net margin is 15.6%, below the 18.1% level a year earlier, while those same bullish assumptions rely on margins rising into the low 20% range over the next few years, so investors need to decide whether today‚Äôs margin profile is a temporary step on that path or a sign that the ramp could be slower.
Bulls see the gap between the US$245.89 share price and modelled fair values as an opportunity, but these FY 2026 margins and growth rates are exactly what they point to when debating how quickly Autodesk can earn into that premium.

Next Steps
